frontmatter.title: Analysis on the Life Expectancies of Countries (1990-2021)
frontmatter.subtitle: An in-depth study into the varying life expectancies of countries from 1990 to 2021

children.value: From 1990 to 2021, the world generally celebrated a consistent increase in average life expectancy. This increase was likely a result of numerous key factors, including: the expansion of medical infrastructure across the world (hospitals, vaccines, proper nutrition), the lack of major wars, and the overall increase in human happiness due to economic prosperity. However, not all countries attained an equitable increase in life expectancy, largely due to their pre-existing human development groups. A pandemic in 2020 was also responsible for the abrupt decline in life expectancy across the world, leading to speculation that the meteoric rise in life expectancy may not recover.
Average Life Expectancy of the World (1990-2021)

children.label: Average Life Expectancy of the World (1990-2021)

children.value: As detailed in the line graph above, the average life expectancy of the world

from 1990-2019. Our team hypothesizes that the increase in life expectancy can be directly correlated with the economic and lifestyle advancements during this time period. The initial rise in the 1990s likely stemmed from more countries embracing free market capitalism after the collapse of the

, increasing the purchasing power of millions of people. Furthermore, the effects of the Green Revolution were also present, with bountiful agricultural yields also increasing life expectancy by reducing the rate of famine.
A Year in Decline: The COVID-19 Pandemic

children.label: A Year in Decline: The COVID-19 Pandemic

children.value: The trend seen in the line graph came to an abrupt end in 2020, when the COVID-19 pandemic swept the world and killed millions of people. Although the actual causes of life expectancy decrease remained somewhat constant, the overall uptick in deaths across the world served to decrease average life expectancy considerably. Notably, the decrease affected all human development groups evenly, even countries that had access to better medical infrastructure.
Comparing Life Expectancies Across Human Development Groups

children.label: Comparing Life Expectancies Across Human Development Groups

children.value: As extrapolated from the bar graph above, countries can be divided into 4 Human Development Groups: Low, Medium, High, and Very High. The criteria for these Development Groups is based on a variety of factors, including quality of life, economic prosperity, and access to medical infrastructure. A majority of countries are placed into either the High or Very High groups, suggesting that they should also yield higher average life expectancies, whereas Low and Medium countries will generally have lower life expectancies. This conclusion is supported in the graph below:

children.value: This data set is only a fraction of all countries!
Average Growth In Life Expectancy by Human Development Level
Average Growth in Life Expectancy per annum
Using the graph, we can derive equations that project and model the growth of life expectancy per annum of a group of countries.

children.label: my-equation
children.value:
\text{Low Development: } l = 0.469x + 47.487 \\
\text{Medium Development: } l = 0.306x + 58.552 \\
\text{High Development: } l = 0.204x + 67.775 \\
\text{Very High Development: } l = 0.218x + 73.432 \\


\\Where
\\
\\
\text{l = average life expectancy}\\
\text{x = years since 1990}\\

children.value: Upon examining the overall linear regressions of each Human Development Group, two trends emerge: Firstly, despite an abrupt halt to life expectancy increase due to the COVID-19 Pandemic, all human development groups are still forecasted to grow their life expectancies into the future (perhaps at a decreased rate). Secondly, it is apparent that countries in the Low Human Development Group have undertaken a remarkable transformation in life expectancy increase, which is highlighted by the slope of the Low countries being the steepest. Our team suspects that this is due to the natural principle of diminishing returns: The higher a country starts out on the Human Development Index, the less potential it has for life expectancy growth, whereas countries designated as Low Development are destined to rapidly increase their life expectancies due to burgeoning technological and medical advancements.
Our team suggests that for future cases of life expectancy data analysis, data sets containing vaccination rates for the COVID-19 virus should be considered.

In conclusion, our team ascertained that there were a variety of factors involved in the rapid increase of the world’s average life expectancy from 1990-2019, as well as substantial evidence to understand why this trend collapsed during the COVID-19 pandemic from 2020-2021. During this time period, quality of life generally increased across all countries, leading to better living conditions that increased the average life expectancy.

Using linear regression, we have also come to the conclusion that on average, countries with currently low development seem to increase life expectancy far faster than countries with current high development, up to double. We believe that this is due to the fact that the current life expectancy is very low for modern standards, so it is easier to improve compared to a fully optimized country like many of the high-development countries. Conversely, the higher a country’s life expectancy is, the less potential it has to grow.

Lastly, we can conclude that life expectancy is not equitable among countries, due to each country being placed into different Human Development Groups: Low, Medium, High, and Very High. Countries in the higher categories tend to have a higher HDI (Human Development Index) score, as well as more advanced medical infrastructure, leading to their expected higher life expectancies. On the contrary, countries in the Low Human Development Group have poor access to vital new technologies and medical advancements, correlating to their lower average life expectancies.

Barbieri_2015.html: Barbieri, M., Wilmoth, J. R., Shkolnikov, V. M., Glei, D., Jasilionis, D., Jdanov, D., Boe, C., Riffe, T., Grigoriev, P., & Winant, C. (2015). Data Resource Profile: The Human Mortality Database (HMD). International Journal of Epidemiology, 44(5), 1549–1556. 10.1093/ije/dyv105
